awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: Eco-evolutionary dynamics of coastal marsh responses to rising CO2
awd_abstract_narration:
Salt marshes protect coastal communities from flooding events, regulate water quality, and serve as nursery grounds that maintain fisheries. Environmental changes can have a significant impact on salt marsh ecology. This project will examine the synergistic effects of two environmental changes on salt marsh ecology - increases in atmospheric CO2 and rising sea levels. The impacts of increases in atmospheric CO2 will be assessed by studying evolutionary responses of salt marsh plant growth patterns. The impacts of rising sea level will be examined by testing whether such changes in marsh plant growth patterns result in in marsh stabilization by elevating the sediment surface of the marsh, and in turn maintaining marsh ecosystem function. Understanding these relationships may aid in effective coastal management and enable society to better anticipate and manage socioeconomic consequences of environmental change. Undergraduate and graduate students at two universities will be directly involved in the design and implementation of experimental work in the project. The project also will make findings from the work accessible to coastal managers and the public.

This research project will assess the role that genetically-based changes in a key salt marsh plant, Schoenoplectus americanus, has played in marsh persistence over a 100-year period. Genotypes spanning the last century will be retrieved from dormant seeds buried in sediments. The project will determine differences in plant traits, including growth rates and tissue allocation, across cohorts of "resurrected" genotypes using field, laboratory, and classroom-based experiments. The project will then incorporate results into the Marsh Ecosystem Model (MEM), to project the impact of changes in plant performance over the last century on the stability and persistence of salt marsh ecosystems. Broader societal impacts from this study will include a rare assessment of the contribution that evolutionary responses make to the function of a highly valued ecosystem. Because the societal benefits of salt marshes can be strengthened or weakened by environmental changes on decadal and centennial scales, it is important to determine the extent to which evolution of biological traits can amplify or dampen the likelihood of ecosystem persistence. The project will facilitate access to the Marsh Ecosystem Model (MEM) to researchers and managers via the PEcAn platform.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: Coastal salt marshes maintain themselves in the face of rising sea level largely through the growth of plant tissues: Belowground plant tissue, like roots and rhizomes, contribute to soil volume, while aboveground tissues, like stems, catch suspended sediments. In the Chesapeake Bay, both processes contributed to the accretion of wetland soils at a rate that has allowed these ecosystems to persist against a background of modest historical sea-level rise. Today's acceleration of sea-level rise threatens to overwhelm this naturally stabilizing process, and this occurs in the context of other novel environmental changes affecting plant biology, like nutrient runoff and rising atmospheric CO2. Decades of research have produced an integrated understanding of how most biological processes (plant physiology, demography, species interactions, etc) contribute to the persistence of coastal salt marshes, but evolutionary changes in plant traits have not been studied. This knowledge gap is likely due both to the difficulty of developing empirical estimates of rates of evolutionary change and to skepticism that evolution over mere decades could alter plant traits strongly enough to alter ecosystem function.

In this project, we were able to measure evolutionary changes in the biological traits of a common salt marsh species, chairmaker's bullrush (Schoenoplectus americanus) over 100 years, and to demonstrate that these changes were sufficiently large to influence the stability and the function of salt marshes. First, we demonstrated that we could resurrect long-dormant seeds from this species from sediment cores, and that the genetic make-up of these plants changed over the last century (genetic evidence of evolution). Then we experimentally compared the growth of modern and ancestral plants under controlled conditions in mesocosm experiments in Chesapeake Bay (Figure 1). 

These experiments showed that plant traits, especially the abundance and vertical distribution of belowground tissues, evolved over the past century in two ways that have implications for the function and stability of salt marshes. First, the average volume and rooting depth of belowground tissues shrunk over this time period. These changes in the biology of this species were large enough that both the storage of carbon in sediments and the ability of the sediment surface to rise at a pace matching sea-level rise have been reduced (Figure 2). Second, we found that the evolutionary flexibility of plants responding to environmental change, "phenotypic plasticity," also changed over the last century (Figure 3). An example of reduced phenotypic plasticity: bullrushes growing under brackish and more inundated conditions, increasingly common as sea-level rises, may be less capable of capitalizing on the advantages to photosynthesis provided by rising CO2.

In most models of ecosystem change, biological traits are fixed and invariant. Our study challenges these assumptions. In coastal salt marshes 10 to 30% of trait variation was due to genetic variation and evolutionary trends, which are ignored in existing models of coastal response to sea-level rise. Evolution can happen on the scale of anthropogenic environment change; it is measurable; and it is large enough to affect the fate of entire ecosystems.

Broader Impact: Salt marshes are unique ecosystems that protect coastal communities from storm surge, store carbon away from the atmosphere, and serve as nurseries for economically important fisheries. Coastal environments are also experiencing rising sea-level, nutrient pollution, and atmospheric CO2. This project showed that evolution is an important process to include in forecasts of the fate of these systems. This result suggests that evolution may be generally important to consider when anticipating the future of ecosystem services to society. This theme of integrated environmental-biological systems has also been integrated into teaching and training from this project. Active researchers on the project included 6 graduate students, 10 technicians, 5 research associates, 45 undergraduate researchers, and a postdoc. At Notre Dame and the University of Tennessee, classroom teaching used this project to discover how basic biology contributes to the persistence of ecosystems and the services they provide to society. A highlight was the 300+ Notre Dame undergraduates who integrated active engagement with our research team to conduct semester-long research projects on this project, most of them as their first college-level laboratory course.
